Root cause and corrective actions are determined and formal reports are prepared.  Progress regarding corrective action on all investigated incidents is tracked through final resolution.	
	
Emergency response Program
	
Michigan Milk Producers Association emergency evacuation plan has been designed to address likely incidents arising from our ammonia refrigeration system.  The emergency plan is a vital part of Michigan Milk Producers Association's overall prevention program.  Michigan Milk Producers Association continues to plan how to address the unplanned release of ammonia while striving to adhere to the latest mechanical integrity practices and technologies.

	
Planned improvements to reduce risk
	
In accordance with its risk management program, Michigan Milk Producers Association conducts continuous self-examination evaluations designed to identify and assess process/operational risks to employees and the community.  

Ammonia detectors are strategically located throughout the facility to quickly detect any releases.

ment organizations.  This ensures prompt response and mitigation actions during incidents.
	
Facility description and regulated substances handled
	
Michigan Milk Producers Association is a producer of fluid milk products. It is located at 125 Depot Street in Constantine, Michigan, St. Joseph County.
	
Only one chemical covered by 40 CFR Part 68 is inventoried at the Constantine site.  This substance is present in quantities greater than the threshold quantity identified by the RMP regulation and therefore is included in our risk management program.

Ammonia (anhydrous) - Ammonia is used as a refrigerant at the plant.  It is received into the plant by cylinders; however, deliveries of ammonia are infrequent.  
	
Accidental release program & chemical-specific prevention steps
	
Michigan Milk Producers Association contracted with an outside consulting firm to assist in the refinement of the prevention program tailored exclusively to ammonia refrigeration operations.  This prevention program was designed around a management program that includes the development of system & equipment operating procedures, maintaining the mechanical integrity of the equipment, and training of the operators on the proper operation of the system.  The primary objective of the prevention program is to ensure the complete containment of ammonia through safe operation and maintenance of the refrigeration system.
	
Michigan Milk Producers Association completed a process hazard analysis (PHA) of the ammonia refrigeration system as part of their commitment to safety and the facility continues to revalidate it every five years and update it as needed.
	
Five-year accident history
	
Michigan Milk Producers Association has not had an event occur in the last five years that meets the EPA definition of an accident that caused injuries, deaths, or significant property damage on-site, or injuries, deaths, environmental damage, property damage, evacuations, or shelters-in-place off-site.
	
In the event

Accidental Release Prevention and Emergency Response Policies

The accidental release prevention and emergency response policies at Michigan Milk Producers Association in Constantine, Michigan facility are engrained in the fundamentals of the process safety prevention program.
	
At the Constantine, Michigan facility anhydrous ammonia is used for refrigeration.  The refrigeration system has an inventory of ammonia that is considered hazardous by the Environmental Protection Agency (EPA).  The same properties that make this chemical valuable as a refrigerant also make it necessary to observe specific safety precautions.  These safety precautions are exercised in the operation and maintenance of the refrigeration system to control human environmental exposure in an effort to reduce the overall threat to workers as well as the surrounding communities and the environment.
	
It is Michigan Milk Producers Association's policy to adhere to all applicable federal, state, and local laws, rules, and regulations.  However, the safe handling of ammonia is paramount at Michigan Milk Producers Association.  Standards and recommended practices governing the safe handling of ammonia are used to ensure that a reasonable level of risk reduction is maintained.  Safety depends upon management commitment, the manner in which ammonia refrigerant is handled, the safety devices inherent to the refrigeration system design, operating procedures and philosophies, and the training of Michigan Milk Producers Association workers.
	
The Emergency Evacuation Plan outlines procedures for warned and unwarned emergencies that may occur at the plant.  Warned emergencies are usually tornadoes, heavy snowstorms, or conditions that are reasonably predictable.  Unwarned emergencies usually consist of onsite emergencies such as a spill, fire/explosion, or chemical release.
